Gmail is astounding. Today I sent a few emails and saw the magic of "conversation view", as Gmail calls it. Instead of storing each email separately, the Gmail user sees emails in context with their replies. This is especially good for referring to a conversation you forgot about. The interface is sleek and Google-style cool/functional. Instead of loading new pages all over the place like most web email, Gmail shows a small "Loading" in the corner of the screen, and even on my slow dialup, loads quickly. Problem is, all this coolness is made possible by JavaScript. Browsers without it, like the one on my T-Mobile Sidekick, can't use Gmail. One flaw in a great design so far.

"Time is an illusion. Lunchtime doubly so." - Ford Prefect, The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy , by Douglas Adams So better grab your PB&J lunch break while you can ;) But this is, actually, a book rec, in disguise as a clever reply to Carson's post, which made me think of it. If ANYONE reading this has not read the all of the above-mentioned book/trilogy/series, or any of it, OR -insert scandalized gasp of horror here- perchance has not heard of Douglas Adams at ALL - GET THEE TO A BOOKSTORE!! Especially if you're a Discworld fan. Douglas Adams is a lot like Terry Pratchett plus spaceships, more random humor & wackiness, and minus magic, giant Moving turtles, and any semblance of a plotline whatsoever. XD Put it this way: if you're reading this blog, you ought to also be reading Douglas Adams. There is no other way. And for all you fanfiction geeks out there: Douglas Adams is, IMO, the creator of the world's longest, best, and FUNNIEST PWP - in the PG-13, ff.net, original sense of the acronym. So go read it!! NOW!

Some elements of all road trips are similar and should be noted. Now, as I'm on one (not driving, don't worry) I feel I ought to note them here before I stop caring about it. 1. Food. The chain "Country Kitchen" is one I would not eat at, ever, save those frequent road trip visits. The reason? It exists in a parallel universe accessible only to road travelers. Similarly, "real" restaurants like the ones you eat at back home and when you get where you're going, are excluded from this universe. Probably to give Country Kitchen more business. 2. Shops. On road trips, and only on road trips, signs like "Used Usables" pop up everywhere. "Amish Furnishings and Canned Goods" exists in the same parallel universe as Country Kitchen. 3. Broad generalizations. On all road trips, bloggers have the urge to make hugely broad generalizations. Now excuse me please while I figure out how to get 134 Mason jars of peaches and an oak table from the Amish market in my trunk.

It's around 1:30 and I just got back from a returns party for Claire McCaskill (claireonline.com), a Democratic contender for Missouri governor. Tonight we watched the results come in and found out that she beat incumbent Bob Holden in the Democratic primaries. I hadn't been to one of these things before. They are definitely interesting. If you're interested in the results, that is. We watched Holden concede on a big screen that had been playing results from the local news all night, and then Claire stepped up and talked about beating the Republicans in November. Very cool. If you have the chance to do something like this, I recommend it. Get involved in politics in your area. And hey, if you live in Missouri, please send some money urlLink Claire's way. Blunt, her Republican opponent, is very well funded and had little primary trouble.
